Description: Ability to write clean, efficient code that solves problems correctly.
Level 1: Basic: Cannot complete basic coding tasks. Code is buggy and unreadable.
Level 2: Intermediate: Completes basic tasks with some guidance. Code works but lacks optimization.
Level 3: Advanced: Writes clean, efficient code independently. Handles edge cases well.
Level 4: Expert: Writes elegant, highly optimized code. Mentors others on best practices.

Description: Understanding of system architecture and ability to design scalable solutions.
Level 1: Basic: No understanding of system design concepts.
Level 2: Intermediate: Basic understanding of components but struggles with integration.
Level 3: Advanced: Designs functional systems with good scalability considerations.
Level 4: Expert: Architects complex distributed systems. Anticipates future scaling needs.

Description: Analytical thinking and ability to break down complex problems.
Level 1: Basic: Cannot break down problems. Gets stuck without guidance.
Level 2: Intermediate: Breaks down simple problems but struggles with complexity.
Level 3: Advanced: Systematically approaches complex problems with clear methodology.
Level 4: Expert: Tackles ambiguous problems creatively. Develops novel solutions.

Description: Deep knowledge in specific technical domains relevant to the role.
Level 1: Basic: Surface-level knowledge only. Cannot explain concepts in depth.
Level 2: Intermediate: Understands fundamentals but gaps in advanced topics.
Level 3: Advanced: Strong depth in core areas. Can explain complex concepts clearly.
Level 4: Expert: Expert-level depth. Contributes to technical standards and innovation.

Description: Ability to work effectively with cross-functional teams.
Level 1: Basic: Works in isolation. Poor communication with team members.
Level 2: Intermediate: Collaborates when required but doesn't proactively engage.
Level 3: Advanced: Strong collaborator. Communicates clearly with PM, Design, and other engineers.
Level 4: Expert: Drives cross-team initiatives. Builds bridges between departments.

Description: Ability to review code effectively and provide constructive feedback.
Level 1: Basic: Cannot provide meaningful code review feedback.
Level 2: Intermediate: Catches basic issues but misses architectural concerns.
Level 3: Advanced: Provides thorough reviews covering correctness, style, and architecture.
Level 4: Expert: Sets code review standards. Mentors others on effective reviewing.
